course.name: Principles of Accounting II
course.description: For SB&M students, and programs that designate the course as a required/specified elective course. This is the second course of the principles of accounting sequence. It introduces concepts, accounting methods, and analytical tools related to managerial and cost accounting. Topics include fundamental cost concepts, job-order and process costing systems, CVP analysis, budgets and standards, segment reporting, and decision-making using cost information.

He probably could have left UST last year or something, but he decided to stay here cuz he couldn't miss the 2000-ft accommodations (with a 360-degree superb panorama of greenery and ocean blue) UST had offered to him, and probably also the gym room in UST. Okay I FF'ed too much.
reviews.comment_grading:
‚úèÔ∏è Quiz 1 (Closed book üìò)
Process costing is the most difficult chapter for quiz 1, so it's DEFINITELY gonna appear on the exam paper. Just make sure you know how to prepare the statements ALL BY YOURSELF.

I fxxked up the first quiz, getting 6 marks below the median. I just didn't fxxking understand process costing. The mean was just fxxking high.

‚úèÔ∏è Quiz 2 (Closed book üìò)
All the contribution margin thingy. Needs to prepare the full absorption costing statement and the variable costing statement. Includes the allocation of resources with 1 constraint using accounting method (NOT linear programming). The last question was on opportunity cost and it was basically a game of all-or-none - you either got all 8 credits or you lost all. See the attachment for the question he asked.

This time I did better, with 1 SD above mean.

‚úèÔ∏è Final Exam (Open book üìñ)
Difficult as hell. I'd no idea what was going on even with all the printed notes on my table. I couldn't even finish the paper even though it's a full 3-hour exam.

As usual, there were 5 MCs and 3 long questions. The MCs (10 marks out of 120) were probably the only questions you could get them with a certain level of certainty. The remaining 3 LQs... Good luck!!!

The first question was on budgetary planning. Tricky and complicated as hell. The first few parts on preparing production budgets looked like free marks for us, but in fact they were already tricky in the sense that they changed the assumption of the inventory level. If you just copied the example on the lecture slides you'd flunk the whole question from the very beginning. The direct labor budget was extremely confusing because there were 2 types of workers working for the same product, and I had utterly no idea how to allocate the number of units produced for each of them. (At last to make it simple, I made an assumption that these 2 types of workers were working in series, not in parallel, to produce the products. Dunno if this is acceptable...) The SG&A budget was another trap cuz the linear regression result he gave you was on a yearly basis, so don't forget to divide the fixed cost by 12 (and we also probably needed to state the assumption that the expenses are incurred evenly/linearly throughout the 12 months blah blah blah...) For those who also divided the variable cost by 12, go back to Chapter 2 to check how we dealt with cost drivers. Then it came to the cash budget and the income statement where I needed to go back and forth and recalculate lots of stuff again for the previous month (and the previous month of the previous month for the uncollected sales revenue). Fxxk it. I dunno if I've overlooked any hidden trap or made any minor miscalculation for such a long question.

The second question was basically capital budgeting and probably it was the easiest as soon as you spent some time carefully identifying the cash flows. But it was still a little tricky cuz some of the costs were irrelevant. After the exam I heard someone discussing how to calculate the depreciation using the double-declining-balance method. Hold on... You didn't even need to calculate depreciation (for both the new and the old machines) because
üî∂ Depreciation is NOT out-of-pocket cash outflow
üî∂ The operating income Allen gave us was CASH income which meant that you didn't need to add back depreciation to get the cash inflow.
üî∂ No tax. So no depreciation tax shield.
So it was basically just something Allen purposefully put down to daunt us, or a hint by Allen that we didn't need to care about the depreciation thingy at all. And also just don't forget how to deal with the net working capital. Seriously without taxes included (and the related opportunity cost of the forgone depreciation tax shield for the old machine) and with the cash income directly given to us, the question was already much simpler, when compared to the one in the finance course.

The third question (variance analysis) was the one I fxxked up the most seriously. It was basically about the situation when a few factors changed (raw material suppliers, direct labor hour rate, efficiency, etc), how these affected the production budget. All questions discussed in class was on the total number of units produced, but this one in the exam was on a per-unit basis and no information about the number of units was provided, so I'm not sure if we still have volume variance anymore. For part (a) I didn't even know whether or not the question was actually asking us to do the variance analysis. Part (b) - I ran out of time. Didn't even have the time to read the question and left the whole question blank. I think I'm gonna lose all the 28 marks. It's FUCKING 28 MARKS!!!!!!

I had NO TIME to double-check my answers. It was VERY likely that I'd made calculation mistakes for such long questions. I finally understood what he meant by "budgeting our time carefully" on the instruction page.

üíØ Dunno what happened to my final. Got A- at the end. Seems you can fuck up 1 out of 3 LQs in the final and crash 1 of the 2 quizzes to secure an A-.

Lastly, I must pay my full respect to all those who major accounting.

The quizzes were relatively easy to other courses. The professor was actually expecting higher means, with him saying that he was expecting quiz 1 & 2 to be ~80. One-hour quizzes had 14 and 17 questions and time pressure increased as the course progressed, culminating in a 1.5 hour final with 26 questions. My tip is to always make an Excel or notes, then rehearse all the questions possible in the book. The calculator is more important in the first two quizzes, but Excel is a necessity in the final exam because topics are complex and since Chapter 11 exists (use =NPV and =IRR).
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload. There's a problem set graded based on effort but the time allotted is pretty much one whole month. No worries about that.

For the quizzes, try to internalize the concepts by making a cheatsheet or doing an Excel. I'm a fan of the latter. Make sure to do ALL if not MOST of the exercises on the book since these will solidify your understanding. Some questions are more straightforward in the quizzes, while in the final, there were two to three convoluting questions that even Excel could not help in.

Time pressure for the quizzes are okay, but you still probably don't have time to question yourself. Time pressure for the final is insane and without Excel, I probably would not have answered all the questions. I basically skipped 2-3 questions since I couldn't figure it out or it required too much work but was lucky with the outcome for the other questions it seems.

reviews.comment_grading:
I rank a ‚ÄúB‚Äù here not because Li Xinlei gave bad grades, indeed, in terms of percentage curve, I believe she gave the max A-range already. However, the problem is the design of quizzes.

Let me share the scheme first:
Quizzes 75% (Best 3 out of 4, each 25%)
Individual Case Project 15%
Assignments 10% (Based on effort, 10 out of 11)

Doing assignments yourself without copying online sources will help with understanding the course contents and hence prepare better for the quizzes. (And btw she will randomly pick some homework and check. Doesn‚Äôt matter you did it correctly or not but definitely not selfie this time, please)

For the quizzes, however, she allocated the number of questions and the score for each question quite awkward in the sense that you may be tricked about the score and time distribution. As an example, her first quiz included 13 questions with a 60-minute duration. The first 9 questions were of 1.25 points each, everyone expected each question worths 1.25 points, so we spent around 40 mins finishing up to the 9th question, then when we jumped to the 10th question, it is 10.75 points, the 11th and 12th questions were 7 points each, the last one was worth 14 points. And the max. score is 50. Lol.

Also, I think that the later three quizzes were designed way too easy, such that everyone got very high marks, so that the grade division was narrow, losing 2-3 points overall means a difference in sub-grade.

But apart from the ‚Äúweird‚Äù design of quizzes, the gradings are fine. Tho imo the markings of the case project was a little bit too vague and lenient such that the mean was 13.9 out of 15 and failed to differentiate students‚Äô abilities enough.

10 Assignments, they are easy yet lengthy. Try to complete all as they will help with your quizzes. TA may randomly pick some assignments to check whether you have finished. Don‚Äôt submit a selfie to canvas.

reviews.comment_content:
General Managerial Accounting stuff. Beneficial for students who studied BAFS in secondary school.

Nearly no memorization is needed. Skills for solving more advanced and complicated questions are required. It‚Äôs important to understand what the professor talked in the lectures and some details about the cases given in class, as they will be tested in exams.

Overall easy content and not so time-consuming. Read the e-book and do the quizzes helped me a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent teaching with interactive classes and engaging experience.

Probably the best professor I met. He gives clear explanations with interesting examples. He also lists out the topics needed to be learnt for each lesson and before exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two midterms, each with about 20 MCs, 3 hours. Weighting: 25% each

One final, 20MCs, 3 hours. 40%.

Participation: 10%. The professor said that he takes a picture of the classroom every time for compulsory lectures.

The questions are not easy, many students took all 3 hours to complete the paper.

However, the mean is pretty high, about 85%. Therefore, the course is easy to study but hard to get a good grade.

I got about 95% overall, A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Two 1.5-hour lectures per week, one of them is optional. However, stuffs in the optional lecture will also be tested, so better attend both lectures.

The e-book is useful, with detailed explanation and quizzes. It is noted that one or two exam questions were the exact questions in the online quizzes.

Overall light workload, but need some extra work in order to differentiate you from others for an A range.

reviews.title: A professor that makes you laugh every lesson

A humorous professor. The teaching quality is extremely good. Although no attendance was counted, I wished to attend his lesson every week. He told us " Accounting is fun" and really demonstrated how fun accounting is.
You should definitely reg Derrald's course even if you are not interested in accounting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two midterms (will drop the lowest one)
One final exam
Fairly graded
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was very light, no projects, no homework, only exams.

reviews.comment_content: Most of the contents are taught in secondary school.
reviews.comment_teaching: very detailed notes. The instructor answered the questions with simple and understandable examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since the mid-term exams were very easy, the mean was high.
There's bonus question in the first mid-term but not many people got it (no partial credit).

Instructors may adjust the final grade because of the major you are in, but no detail information for that.

Attendance is not required but there's group exercise in one of the lecture (just attending the lecture and finishing the exercise is fine already).

Final exam (opened-book exam). Questions are much more difficult than mid-term exam, but they are just the advanced version of the questions. Reviewing the textbook and notes will help.

reviews.title: Course review
reviews.comment_content:
The content is useful and interesting. For accounting, we may think of only financial staffs, but this course which teaches managerial accounting explain how company measure its performance from another perspective.
It includes lecture and online studying, which is more flexible and diverse. Also it includes some important case studying.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is really perfect. I have 9:00am class but I also never fell asleep because professor is energetic. Half of the class day is optional, which you can choose to learn online by yourself and it provides you with flexibility.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is standard ratio.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly quiz is a little bit harsh but submission makes full grade. Apart from it only are midterm and final.

reviews.author: Dreamscometrue
reviews.title: Management Accounting
reviews.comment_content:
Stuffs on management accounting, which is tools for helping companies to make decision, mostly for internal control.

Contents are easy if you have studied dse accouting, although some topics are extended, the logic behind is still the same. Even if you have not, it won't be difficult for you to catch up.

Some capital budgeting concepts are involved, just recall FINA2303 concepts, they are much easier in this course. Derrald also allows us to use financial calculators so that's not really a big deal.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Derrlad is an energetic professor who definitely illustrates the concepts and ideas to classess effectively. Sometimes he talks about how to manage your life but not only a company. That's interesting really.

He sometimes ends classes 20 minutes before original end time, his lessons are relaxing also, enough time for discussions (well, and chatting) are provided.

Derrald would provide a handout with all the discussion questions in class, answers are written on the ppt which will be posted on canvas after classes.

Don't be scared by 3 timeslots, only one is compulsory, another one is optional class, you can self learn it in the learning package. The remaining timeslot is fake, no classes there. He also allows you to sit in any session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair. Not as good as mentioned previously. I am not sure about the general grading, but I know that if you get marks higher than mean <1sd, it will be a B+, so normal grading.

He lists out many criteria in assessing your participation, but as he allows students to come in any sessions with no participation marking, I guess the parti marks are just...you interpret it :)
reviews.comment_workload:
0 workload nearly
2 simple midterms will all MCQs
1 final with MCQ-style short questions
Some optional quizzes

Not project will be good .

reviews.comment_content: For SB&M students, and programs that designate the course as a required/specified elective course. This is the second course of the principles of accounting sequence. Topics include fundamental cost concepts, job-order and process costing systems, CVP analysis, budgets and standards, segment reporting, and decision-making using cost information.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I really liked the professor's style of delivering lessons. He is very brief and clear with his message. Gives real-life examples or in-class exercises that help students understand some possibly-difficult questions.
He handed out prints once in every week and let students solve them. No attendance check and the professor allows you to come to any time slots.

With him, I personally found Managerial Accounting really fun and easy-going actually.
reviews.comment_grading:
As long as I remember, there was no mid-term but one or two substitute quizzes. I personally felt them not difficult at all and the time was more than enough to double-check the answers. Easier quizzes or exams may not be helpful if you are aiming for an A+. So just like all the other accounting courses, be careful with your numbers during exams! :)
reviews.comment_workload:
I wouldn't say there was a lot of workload (considering it is an accounting course) but it was quite bothersome to watch videos, read e-Book, and finish quizzes on Internet every once or twice in a week. From certain point of time, I quit listening to video lectures but it did not affect me much so I guess it is more of a supplement rather than a must.
Each quiz consists of 5 or 10 questions and is marked immediately. Quizzes are usually very simple, covering basic concepts from each chapter.
This system pretty much forces you to keep focused throughout the semester, yet it may help you from putting all-nighters days before the exams.

Before you enroll to this course, be sure you judge yourself wisely. If you are more of a person who prefers to chill out throughout the semester and suffers few days or weeks right before exams, this course may not be a good fit for you.

No need to memorize the exact formats of financial statements. Understanding the basic concepts would be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: Stice is a caring teacher who shows much enthusiasm towards accounting. In his lessons, he would not only discuss the important principles of accounting, he would also spend some time explaining the intuition behind, which is really good but the intuition is not covered in exams. The intuition can be some recommendations raised by consultants. For example, given financial problems indicated by the accounting tool, how can the company overcome the problems? Personally, as I've heard Stice is conducting classes for MBA, I hope to attend some of his lessons. A really good teacher.
reviews.comment_grading: Stice is lenient in grading. There are two midterm exams in the semester. But Stice allows skipping the exams and moving the weight to the final. Also, although it seems strange, in case of scoring low in the midterm, the scores can be removed by asking to shifting the weight to the final. There is a question in the final exam of whether you would like to shift the weight of midterms to the final. For my performance, 21/21 and 24/24 in two midterms, 18/20 in the final predicted, an A+ in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Attending all the lessons is fine. It is not necessary to spend so much time in this subject. But it is important to have finished the exercises Stice has given, which may appear again in the exams.

Tips for students taking the course:
- Make an Excel on your own and make sure you fully understand it ( The quizzes are not hard, many questions are repeat concepts and are reskinned versions of the textbook ones, however, the calculations are tedious, and IMO it's very very difficult with just a normal calc)
- Make sure you participate in EVERY canvas discussion. A smart strategy is just to post dumb questions you already know the answers to. Many of my peers did this and they scored full participation.
- Do the Practice Case Final, it is your ONLY chance to get feedback on something remotely similar to what you'll get in the final. Also, do some praying :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Objectively speaking Dr. Morris is one of the better professors at HKUST. He is engaging and not monotone like many profs are. He is knowledgeable in his field and he frequently relates his past experience in the field to the content he is teaching. I would give his teaching prowess an A/A+ rating.

Although I am more than willing to sing his praises in terms of his teaching ability, I think the course design ( Absolute grading + subjective essay marks with high ambiguity and little transparency) is really really BAD. I would recommend finding another session with non-absolute grading if possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:

Canvas Quiz Discussion 10% (5/10)
"10% of your grade will be based upon the frequency and quality of your Canvas discussions, infrequent or low-quality posts will not receive full credit."
"Canvas Discussion Participation: 10% of your grade will be based on your regular participation on the Canvas discussion board for each chapter. You should post meaningful questions when you have them and help answer other student‚Äôs questions. Though this grade is subjective, students should consider one high quality post per chapter to be the criteria for full credit."

The ACTUAL GRADE is assigned purely based on frequency. i.e for me I only put comments in  5 discussion threads = 5/10, it doesn't matter how many posts u do in each individual one, just need to do all. I screwed this up because I didn't realize frequency is the defining criteria.

Quiz 1: 30% (37/40) mean~ 32/33 ish
Quiz 2: 30% (30/30) mean ~ 24/25 ish
Canvas was closed after the semester ended so the means are only roughly what I rmb

Case-based Final: 30% (70/100 ~ O: M, C: M, P: M)
3 criteria - low-> medium-> high scale
Origninality - Creativity - Practicallity
Task: write a no-word limit essay on a case he assigns during the lesson. The essay is based on a company revealed at the start of lesson. You have till the end of the lesson to write it. This essay is REALLY OPEN-ended, as in you have to identify your own challenge for the company they give you then propose a solution for it. No case brief- just internet. The essay does not have to be directly related to course material although it is suggested to make some links where possible.

In my opinion, this aspect of the course is extremely unfair, the essay grade is mostly subjective and has minimal relation to the course materials. Yet it carries a 30% weighting?! This normally wouldn't be a problem except that the course is graded absolutely. From a student's perspective, this is really unsatisfying because aside from a practice case done in class theres no real way to prepare for it. It feels like you are coin-flipping your grade, and in its current form, I feel believe the course is poorly designed in terms of rewarding students' grades based on the actual course content. (Case Essay + participation ~40%, of course, has almost nothing to do with the course !!!!!!! and it's absolute!!!!)

My Final Grade: B
Disclaimer: Although I am rather dissatisfied with my grade many of my friends achieved much higher(A-), mainly through high participation and Case final grades even though they had mean/ below mean quiz scores. However, some others are also in a similar position to me, with high quiz scores but low mediocre case-final grades.
